content:
gene activity during early development in
Embryology Course, Woods Hole ,Massachusetts
July 19-20, 1988
Eric Wieschaus and Dari Sweeton
The major topic of this lab experiment is the spatial
patterns of transcription which arise during early embryonic
development in Drosophila. In particular, we are interested
in how these patterns directly reflect an underlying maternal
organisation of the egg cytoplasm, and the extent that those
cytoplasmic cues are mediated by a hierarchy of zygotically
active control genes. As probes for zygotic transcription,
we will use three transformant lines in which the structural
gene for -galactosidase has been fused to various Drosophila
control sequences. All three lines were made by Yatsushi
Hiromi when he was in Walter Gehring's lab in Basel..
In one line the cis-acting control sequences
are derived from the 5' region of the segmentation gene fushi
tarazu, This fusion causes -galactisidase to be expressed
at the blastoderm stage in same seven stripe pattern
associated with the wild type gene. One major difference
is that the protein is extremely unstable and is no
longer present by mid-gastrula stages. In contrast, -
galactosidase made at the blastodern stage persists through
out embryogenesis, effectively marking the progeny of all
cells whose precursors expressed the gene.
The other two constructs are artificial and the nature
of the cis-acting control sequences is not understood. In
both cases, the galactoidase (fused to a non-spatially
controlled promotor) has been stabily integrated at various
random sites in the Drosophila genome. Ocassionally, the
site of insertion confers a tissue or region specific pattern
on the expression of galactosidase. It is not known whether
the pattern observed actually reflects the expression of a
Drosophila gene in the vicinity on the insertion site. Be
that as it may, the transformant lines at least provide
markers for particular embryonic lineages. In one
the expresion is apparently limited to the
anterior and posterior midgut devivatives. In the
it is expressed at a late stage in the
mesodermal component of the gonad.
To study how the expression patterns of these constructs
are affected by alterations in maternal cytoplasmic cues, we
will use three different maternal effect mutation.
